awd_titl_txt: Advancing 3D Chemical Imaging: FTIR Spectro-microtomography, FTIR Spectro-microlaminography and Hyperspectral Data Analysis
awd_abstract_narration:
With this award, the Chemical Measurement and Imaging Program of the Division of Chemistry is funding Professors Carol Hirschmugl and Sarah Patch of The University of Wisconsin-Milwaukee to advance three-dimensional (3D) chemical imaging for biologically relevant materials. To meet this challenge, modifications to infrared spectral micro- tomography are to be combined with hyperspectral data analysis tools to evaluate extended two-dimensional samples. The international collaboration between The University of Wisconsin-Milwaukee, Wesleyan University, and the Norwegian University of Life Sciences combines novel instrumentation, forefront image reconstruction algorithms, and physically accurate modeling to produce chemically sensitive 3-dimensional images. The project is expected to provide multi-disciplinary disciplinary student training in a collaborative environment with international dimensions. 

The overall objective of this proposal is to implement Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectro-micro-tomography (SmT) for samples that are extended in two dimensions and to implement limited angle reconstruction algorithms and optimize spectrochemical analysis methods to enhance spectral and image quality. The rationale for this proposal is that data from improved novel chemical imaging techniques combined with advanced data analysis may be able to provide new views of of intact, (bio)chemically complex systems. This project focuses on three-dimensional imaging of biologically relevant samples (e.g, tissues, extended cell cultures, biofilms) or to materials for bioenergy (e.g, algae, wood).  FTIR-SmT aims to generate high contrast results through the acquisition of rich IR absorption spectra for organic materials. Such a capability for sensing chemical distributions for intact samples may provide the foundation for fundamentally new approaches in bioanalytical chemistry, well beyond these studies.

por.por_cntn:
Dr. Carol Hirschmugl and Dr. Sarah Patch, joined by 5 graduate students, at the University of Wisconsin-Milwaukee (UWM) were supported by a National Science Foundation Chemistry grant. The intellectual merit outcomes include 10 peer-reviewed publications (published between 2016-2021), 3 PhD dissertations (published one in 2017 and two in 2019), and presentations at several international and national conferences and meetings.   The broader impacts of the program include the opportunity for this team to work with an international team of scientists on interdisciplinary projects, including both optical design and implementation and chemical imaging applications. During the funding period, the team at University of Wisconsin-Milwaukee worked closely with Dr. Reinhold Blumel at Wesleyan University and Dr. Achim Kohler and his group of graduate students and post-doctoral assistants at the Norwegian University of Life Sciences in Aas, Norway to develop a theoretical understanding of the optical systems that was consistent with the experimental observations.  Large-data analysis methods were employed to evaluate the chemical status of tissues and cells from several biological systems, and the results were published in collaboration with experts from UW Madison, Louisiana State University, Pennington Biomedical Research Center (Baton Rouge, LA), University of Central Florida, and Universita Politecnica delle Marche (Ancona, Italy). 

 

 As a research group, Hirschmugl and colleagues accomplished several goals of their investigation. To facilitate the collection of the required extensive data sets, equipment for the sample positioning control was acquired and commissioned. The accuracy of the positioning, despite many modifications and development of corrective algorithms, was inadequate to pursue extended measurements with the system.  The team therefore pivoted to identifying other measurement techniques to gather similar data sets, and published developments for a complementary method with reduced sample positioning needs.  Methods to evaluate and analyze complex data sets were developed, refined, and disseminated.  These techniques were applied to experimental data sets for further large-data analysis. These efforts led to several presentations and peer-reviewed publications reporting the chemical status of tissues and cells that were generated and maintained under controlled environments.                                                      

 

This program offered many opportunities for the students to work with multiple experts from around the world on both optical developments and a wide range of chemistry-dependent biological applications. The students and professors residing in different locations met frequently through regularly scheduled virtual meetings.  There were two 5-day workshops at the University of Wisconsin-Milwaukee that the principal professors and most of the participating students attended in person.  Hirschmugl and Blumel visited Norway for a 5-day workshop at the Norwegian University of Life Sciences.  Moreover, these events included opportunities for other team members to participate virtually.  The workshops were focused on developing the theoretical underpinnings of the optical systems. Collaborations with international biomedical and biology experts focused on designing and executing experiments to analyze chemically complex tissues and cells.  These efforts led to multiple opportunities for the students to gain additional understanding and insight into the value of chemical imaging, as well as its applications beyond chemistry.
